case_title: Messrs GULBERG KABANA (PVT.) LTD., LAHORE vs COLLECTOR SALES TAX, LAHORE and another
respondant: Collectorate of Customs, Sales Tax and Central Excise, Lahore

accussed_details.name: Messrs GULBERG KABANA (PVT.) LTD.
allegation: Evasion of sales tax amounting to Rs. 509,053
Failure to issue bills for food served in hotel rooms
Exclusion of service charges from sales tax calculations
Contravention of sections 2(37), 3, 6, 7, 22, 23, and 26 of the Sales Tax Act, 1990

complaint_summary: The appellant was accused of evading sales tax amounting to Rs. 509,053 by failing to issue bills for food served in hotel rooms and excluding service charges from sales tax calculations.
investigation_summary: The Collectorate of Sales Tax and Central Excise, Lahore raided the appellant's premises and scrutinized records, revealing discrepancies in sales tax calculations and alleged evasion.
judgment_summary: The Tribunal accepted the appeal, declaring the order-in-original as time-barred and nullity in the eyes of law due to non-compliance with statutory time limits under sections 11(4) and 36(3) of the Sales Tax Act, 1990.
punishment: Penalty of Rs.25,475 imposed under section 33(2)(cc).
Decision_or_verdict: Appeal accepted; impugned order set aside; show-cause notice vacated.
legal_arguments: Mandatory time limit of 45 days for passing order-in-original under sections 11(4) and 36(3) of the Sales Tax Act, 1990.
Failure to obtain extension within stipulated 90 days.
Legal precedents supporting mandatory nature of time limits: 2008 PTD 60, 2009 PTD 762, 2009 PTD 1978.
key_issues: Whether the time limit for passing order-in-original under sections 11(4) and 36(3) is mandatory or directory.
Non-compliance with statutory time limits for adjudication.

maxims.Redundancy of law: A provision of law cannot be rendered redundant or superfluous.

legal_terms.Order-in-original: Initial adjudication order issued by tax authorities.
legal_terms.Show-cause notice: Notice issued to a party to explain or justify actions.

words_and_phrases.Time-barred: Legal action or decision invalid due to expiration of statutory time limit.
words_and_phrases.Nullity in the eyes of law: A decision or action deemed legally void.

summary_vector_notes: The case revolves around alleged sales tax evasion by the appellant, procedural lapses in adjudication, and legal arguments on statutory time limits under the Sales Tax Act, 1990. The Tribunal ruled in favor of the appellant, declaring the order-in-original as time-barred.
